One possible problem related to the Traveling Salesman Problem in Combinatorics is:

A salesman needs to visit 5 cities, numbered from 1 to 5, and return to his starting point. The distances (in kilometers) between each pair of cities are given by the following matrix:

|   | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| 1 | 0 | 10| 20| 5 | 15|
| 2 | 10| 0 | 35| 25| 20|
| 3 | 20| 35| 0 | 30| 10|
| 4 | 5 | 25| 30| 0 | 20|
| 5 | 15| 20| 10| 20| 0 |

What is the shortest possible route that the salesman can take to visit each city exactly once and return to his starting point? What is the total distance traveled?
